newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli court to hear petitions against Netanyahu.
newsitem.headline: Israeli court to hear petitions against Netanyahu.

text.p: Round two in Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's bout with corruption allegations begins on Wednesday with opposition legislators asking judges to order his indictment.

The High Court of Justice will hear five petitions relating to the affair which state attorneys said raised "real suspicions" of corruption against Netanyahu and his justice minister but did not warrant prosecuting them.
Legal experts said chances the court would force state attorneys to press charges were slim.
"The high court will check...every iota of evidence before deciding if to intervene," said law professor Zeev Segal of Tel Aviv university.

Petitioners argue that it was "highly unreasonable" for Netanyahu and Justice Minister Tzachi Hanegbi to have escaped indictment last month after police recommended both be tried for fraud and breach of trust in the ill-fated appointment of an attorney general last January.
Israel's Channel One Television alleged the appointment of lawyer Roni Bar-On was part of a deal to win a plea bargain for key coalition legislator Aryeh Deri in his corruption trial.
Deri is the only figure in the affair to face an indictment. Bar-On, who quit 12 hours after taking office amid a public outcry that he was unqualified for the job, was cleared by prosecutors.
The investigation against Netanyahu's director-general, Avigdor Lieberman, is still being conducted.

"Justice was not served. The state attorney's decision did not take into account the degree of the prime minister's involvement in the affair," one of the petitioners, parliament member Ophir Pines-Paz, told Reuters.
The petitioners also ask judges to appoint a state commission of inquiry to investigate the affair and make police findings public.
Netanyahu, 47, said in a televised speech last month the report issued by prosecutors cleared him of any wrongdoing.

The results of the three-month police probe prompted members of Netanyahu's own government to call for the dismissal of Hanegbi as the country's overseer of justice but the prime minister's coalition has remained intact.
"The bottom line is I didn't commit any crime and the attorney general confirmed that," Netanyahu said last month.
He apologised for any mistakes in the January appointment, but said the media and opposition had tried to use the affair "to overthrow the government".
Earlier this week Netanyahu announced he would not sack Hanegbi, 40, concluding he was still fit for the job.
Asked if Lieberman would remain, Netanyahu said: "Yes, as long as he wants to continue in the post."
Some political analysts had speculated Hanegbi would be shuffled out of the justice ministry if his predecessor Yaakov Neeman is cleared this week of obstructing justice and lying to judges.
Neeman, who stepped down last August after being indicted, will hear the verdict in his own case on Thursday.
